title: Threats to the life of faith

children.title: affluence
children.comment: Literally, ``flowing'' with prosperity. Wealth is not condemned in Scripture but is seen as a good gift of God. However, affluence has its dangers.

children.title: Contempt for the poor or unfortunate
It is for this life only
The shared wealth of the church
agnosticism
children.comment: The inability to decide whether or not God exists. It is characterised by indecision and compromise when faced with the challenge to wholehearted commitment, and is condemned as sinful, inexcusable and unnecessary in the light of God's clear self-revelation.

cschildren.title: Agnosticism is inexcusable in the light of God's self-revelation

children.title: In the person of Jesus Christ
Because God calls for wholehearted commitment
Because God's call demands total obedience

cschildren.title: Agnosticism as a result of ignorance

children.title: Ignorance as a result of rejecting God's truth
Ignorance as a result of sin
Ignorance is no defence against God's judgment
antinomianism
children.comment: A form of spiritual anarchy, which rejects the law as having any place in the Christian life, whether as instructor or as assessor.  Paul's teaching that Christians are free from the law is sometimes misunderstood as antinomian.  But Paul reveres God's law, and teaches believers, who are free from the law as a system of salvation, to keep it out of gratitude for salvation freely given, and because holiness as defined by the law is the Christian calling.

cschildren.title: Antinomianism as a rejection of God's laws

seealsos.comment: The object of these prophecies, Antiochus Epiphanes, foreshadowed the antichrist in his behaviour.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ and his followers accused of antinomianism

children.title: Jesus Christ came to fulfil the law, not abolish it

cschildren.title: Misunderstandings, by opponents and converts alike, about Paul's teaching on freedom from the law

children.title: Paul corrects the Corinthians' interpretation of his teaching as a licence for antinomianism

primaryrefs.comment: The phrase ``Everything is permissible'' is probably the Corinthians' misinterpretation of Paul's teaching.

children.title: apostasy
children.comment: A general falling away from religion or a denial of the faith by those who once held it or professed to hold it. It is frequently described in terms of spiritual adultery and thus provokes the jealous anger of God.

children.title: apostasy, in OT
children.comment: Israel was in danger of abandoning God from her earliest days. The OT frequently warns against apostasy and identifies its likely consequences.

children.title: Apostasy in Egypt and in the desert

seealsos.comment: the death of 3,000 after Aaron made the golden calf
The people rebel against Moses and Aaron after the return of the spies

children.title: Apostasy in the time of the judges
Apostasy in the kingdom of Israel
Apostasy in the kingdom of Judah

seealsos.comment: Hezekiah's reforms to purify the temple

children.title: apostasy, warnings against personal
children.comment: It is possible for individuals to fall away from faith or turn against Jesus Christ. Scripture identifies this danger and warns against its negative consequences.

children.title: apostasy, dealing with personal
children.comment: Individual believers can fall away from faith and be restored. Scripture gives examples of such falling away, and offers advice on how such people should be dealt with pastorally.

children.title: Warnings of the dangers of personal apostasy

seealsos.comment: Those who return to strict observance of Jewish days and festivals have not understood the gospel.

children.title: Warnings against leading others into apostasy
Encouragements to guard against personal apostasy
Examples of those who were restored from apostasy

secondaryrefs.comment: for the account of Peter's reinstatement see Jn 21:15-17
for evidence of John Mark's recovery see 2Ti 4:11

children.title: apostasy, in OT
children.comment: Israel was in danger of abandoning God from her earliest days. The OT frequently warns against apostasy and identifies its likely consequences.

children.title: Apostasy in Egypt and in the desert

seealsos.comment: the death of 3,000 after Aaron made the golden calf
The people rebel against Moses and Aaron after the return of the spies

children.title: Apostasy in the time of the judges
Apostasy in the kingdom of Israel
Apostasy in the kingdom of Judah

seealsos.comment: Hezekiah's reforms to purify the temple

children.title: apostasy, warnings against personal
children.comment: It is possible for individuals to fall away from faith or turn against Jesus Christ. Scripture identifies this danger and warns against its negative consequences.

children.title: apostasy, dealing with personal
children.comment: Individual believers can fall away from faith and be restored. Scripture gives examples of such falling away, and offers advice on how such people should be dealt with pastorally.

children.title: Warnings of the dangers of personal apostasy

seealsos.comment: Those who return to strict observance of Jewish days and festivals have not understood the gospel.

children.title: Warnings against leading others into apostasy
Encouragements to guard against personal apostasy
Examples of those who were restored from apostasy

secondaryrefs.comment: for the account of Peter's reinstatement see Jn 21:15-17
for evidence of John Mark's recovery see 2Ti 4:11

children.title: astrology
children.comment: The study of the stars and planets, based on the pagan assumption that they exercise a decisive influence over human destinies. Scripture rejects such beliefs, insisting upon the total sovereignty of God over his entire creation.

children.title: The worship of heavenly bodies is forbidden
The consultation of stars is condemned

cschildren.title: Astrology at the time of Daniel
Astrologers came to worship the newborn Jesus

children.title: atheism
children.comment: The denial of God's existence and thus also the denial of his word, truth and authority. It is seen in the worship of created things, in human boasting and in the decision to live a life without God which results in godlessness and brings God's judgment.

children.title: Denying God's ability to fulfil his word
Not turning to God in trouble
It results in lack of hope

cschildren.title: God desires to save the atheist

children.title: covenant breakers
children.comment: Covenants were central to OT life, with the result that those who broke covenants, and especially those who violated the covenant between God and Israel, were regarded as a serious threat to social stability.

children.title: The covenant between God and his people
God will remain faithful to his covenant
Covenants made in the sight of God were permanently binding
Condemnation of those who break covenants

cschildren.title: Examples of breaking the covenant with God

children.title: Failing to care for aliens
children.precomment: Aliens living in Israel were regarded as having privileged status amongst Gentiles, and were treated as covenant people in some respects:

children.title: denial of Jesus Christ
children.comment: The making of a conscious, informed decision not to accept Jesus Christ or his claims and teaching.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ was denied by the Jewish people
The consequences of denying Jesus Christ

children.title: Denying Jesus Christ results in judgment
Denying Jesus Christ means replacement by others
To deny Christ is to be denied by Christ

cschildren.title: Warnings against those who deny Jesus Christ
Denial, repentance and restoration: the example of Peter

children.title: Peter's denial predicted by Jesus Christ
Peter declares he will never deny Jesus Christ
Peter denied that he knew Jesus Christ
discouragement
children.comment: A sense of unhappiness arising from a loss of confidence in one's own abilities, in the reliability of God or in the power of the gospel. Discouragement can occur in the Christian life, especially when there is resistance to the gospel or in instances of personal failure. Scripture provides reassurance for those who experience discouragement.

children.title: The Israelites discouraged when on the point of entering the promised land
General warnings not to discourage others

secondaryrefs.comment: James advises against discouraging the Gentiles

cschildren.title: The need to stand with the discouraged

children.title: dishonesty
children.comment: A way of speaking or acting which leads to people being deceived, misled or cheated.

children.title: dishonesty, and God's nature
children.comment: Dishonesty is contrary to the will and nature of God, and so should not be found among the people of God.

children.title: Dishonesty is contrary to the will and nature of God
Dishonesty, like sin, is of satanic origin
God's denunciation of dishonesty in general
The dishonesty of liars and false witnesses
The dishonesty of false prophets and teachers
God's demands for making amends for dishonesty

secondaryrefs.comment: This demonstrated that their repentance was genuine
the result of encountering Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ was not commending the steward's dishonesty but his shrewdness.

children.title: dishonesty, examples of
children.comment: Examples of the dishonest behaviour condemned by God.

seealsos.comment: In this case, they were cheating the LORD.

children.title: dishonesty, and God's nature
children.comment: Dishonesty is contrary to the will and nature of God, and so should not be found among the people of God.

children.title: Dishonesty is contrary to the will and nature of God
Dishonesty, like sin, is of satanic origin
God's denunciation of dishonesty in general
The dishonesty of liars and false witnesses
The dishonesty of false prophets and teachers
God's demands for making amends for dishonesty

secondaryrefs.comment: This demonstrated that their repentance was genuine
the result of encountering Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ was not commending the steward's dishonesty but his shrewdness.

children.title: dishonesty, examples of
children.comment: Examples of the dishonest behaviour condemned by God.

seealsos.comment: In this case, they were cheating the LORD.

children.title: disobedience
children.comment: The refusal to obey someone, especially someone in a position of authority. Scripture insists on the need to obey God at all times.

cschildren.title: Disobedience enters people's hearts for various reasons

children.title: Disobedience comes through greed and lust
Disobedience results from pride and arrogance

seealsos.comment: Ro 11:20 makes it clear that the disobedience spoken of here was unbelief

cschildren.title: Disobedience to God leads to punishment

children.title: Punishment for the disobedience of unbelief
Disobedience, like all sin, can be forgiven
distrust
children.comment: Failure to trust another, or a tendency to be suspicious of others' abilities or intentions. Though sometimes justifiable towards other human beings, such an attitude is never acceptable towards God.

primaryrefs.comment: Joseph's brothers distrusted him because they could not believe he had forgiven them.

seealsos.comment: Jacob distrusted Esau because he thought he was seeking revenge
Sihon distrusted Israel because he suspected a trick
Paul distrusted John Mark, having been let down by him.
Because that generation distrusted God, they failed to enter the promised land
Israel distrusted God in spite of the miracles he had done for her.

children.title: Other examples
children.precomment: Distrust in God involves failure to trust God's promises and placing trust in other things:

children.title: double-mindedness
children.comment: Indicative of insincerity and hypocrisy. God requires wholeheartedness and sincerity from all people, both in their dealings with others and in their worship of him.

cschildren.title: Double-mindedness in dealings with other people
Lack of faith in prayer is equated with double-mindedness

children.title: doubt
children.comment: Uncertainty about the truth and reality of spiritual things, as seen especially in a lack of faith in and commitment to God.

children.title: doubt, nature of
children.comment: Doubt leads to insecurity and lack of trust concerning God's willingness and ability to deliver his people. It also leads to a fear of people and situations.

children.title: Doubt as a questioning of God's words
Doubt as insecurity about relationship with God
Doubt as fear of people and situations
doubt, results of
children.comment: Doubt results in uncertainty and ineffectiveness in the spiritual life of individual believers and of the believing community. God appeals to those who waver to make a clear choice.

children.title: Uncertainty about the meaning of life
Uncertainty about the will of God
Doubt may result in a spiritual decline
Doubt may result in drifting from faith
Doubt may result in faithless action
Doubt brings the risk of God's judgment
Doubt leads to ineffectiveness in prayer
God's appeal for a clear decision
doubt, dealing with
children.comment: Uncertainty may be remedied by gaining assurance from God's word, remembering God's past goodness, reflecting on his power and appealing to his unfailing love. Believers should help the weak with the patience and encouragement that reflects God's own compassion.

children.title: Doubt dealt with by holding on to God's truth
Receiving correction and understanding through God's word
Doubt dealt with by meditating on God's works

primaryrefs.comment: Religious festivals such as Passover provided a permanent reminder of God's past goodness to his people.

children.title: Remembering God's concern for the weak
God's grace to those with doubts

primaryrefs.comment: God responds to Moses' uncertainty by promising a demonstration of his power.

children.title: Pastoral concern for those who doubt
doubt, nature of
children.comment: Doubt leads to insecurity and lack of trust concerning God's willingness and ability to deliver his people. It also leads to a fear of people and situations.

children.title: Doubt as a questioning of God's words

Doubt as fear of people and situations

God's grace to those with doubts

children.title: Pastoral concern for those who doubt
doubters
children.comment: Scripture provides examples of believers who express temporary doubts--in particular about the willingness and power of God to deliver his people, the nature of his purpose, and their own place within the divine plan.

cschildren.title: Examples of those doubting their effectiveness to serve God

children.title: Abraham and Isaac doubt God's protection

primaryrefs.comment: Fearing for his safety, Abraham resorts to deception.

children.title: Moses and Israel in the desert

seealsos.comment: The Israelites doubt God's protection at the Red Sea
Moses doubts God's provision of food
The ten spies doubt God's power to give victory in Canaan

secondaryrefs.comment: The people of Israel are dismayed by the challenge from Goliath
King Ahaz, afraid of the coalition of Syria and Israel turns to Assyria for help
Peter, walking on water, is afraid and begins to sink
The early church does not believe that God has released Peter from prison.

cschildren.title: Believers with doubts about Jesus Christ

children.title: enemies
children.comment: Opponents or hostile forces which pose a threat to people or nations. Scripture identifies Satan as being the particular enemy of God and notes many enemies of the people of God. Scripture urges caution and courage in dealing with such enemies. Jesus Christ had enemies, and he provides an example of Christian conduct in the face of enemies' threats.

children.title: enemies, of Israel and Judah
children.comment: Throughout their history, Israel and Judah contended with enemies committed to their destruction, finding refuge only in their covenant-keeping God.

children.title: The Canaanites and the surrounding nations
Those opposed to the rebuilding under Ezra and Nehemiah
They were often more numerous than Israel
They were determined to destroy Israel
They were often in league with each other
God helped Israel against her enemies
Israel was not to fear them
Israel was to pray for deliverance
Kindness was to be shown to Israel's enemies
Thanksgiving for victory over Israel's enemies
Giving thanks to God was the proper response to victory
Israel often forgot to give thanks to God
God used enemies to chastise Israel

seealsos.comment: Because of his covenant, the LORD was unwilling to destroy Israel completely at the hand of her enemies

children.title: enemies, of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Throughout his life Jesus Christ was opposed by both spiritual and human enemies. He overcame every enemy so that his people might be set free by his victory.

children.title: The enemies of the infant Jesus
Satan as the enemy of Jesus Christ
In the temptation in the wilderness
The Jewish leaders as enemies of Jesus Christ
They plotted to kill Jesus Christ
They had no real reason for hating him
Judas as the enemy of Jesus Christ
The enemies of Jesus Christ succeeded in killing him in accordance with God's will
Jesus Christ did not retaliate but prayed for his enemies
Jesus Christ can change an enemy into a friend
Jesus Christ will ultimately conquer all his enemies
enemies, of believers
children.comment: Christians must expect to face many enemies on account of their faith. Jesus Christ made it clear that such opposition was the inevitable result of commitment to him. Nevertheless, Christians are called upon to love their enemies.

children.title: Christians are enemies of the world because they belong to Jesus Christ
Opposition to Christians is opposition to Jesus Christ
Christians may be killed by their enemies
To love, do good, bless and pray for them
To help and show kindness to them
To show kindness to their beasts of burden
Not to rejoice in their misfortunes
The need to engage in spiritual warfare
God supports his people against their enemies
Death as the last enemy to be destroyed by Jesus Christ
enemy, Satan as the enemy of God
enemies, of Israel and Judah
children.comment: Throughout their history, Israel and Judah contended with enemies committed to their destruction, finding refuge only in their covenant-keeping God.

children.title: The Canaanites and the surrounding nations
Those opposed to the rebuilding under Ezra and Nehemiah
They were often more numerous than Israel
They were determined to destroy Israel
They were often in league with each other

Israel was not to fear them
Israel was to pray for deliverance

Israel often forgot to give thanks to God
God used enemies to chastise Israel

Opposition to Christians is opposition to Jesus Christ

To love, do good, bless and pray for them

Not to rejoice in their misfortunes
The need to engage in spiritual warfare
God supports his people against their enemies
Death as the last enemy to be destroyed by Jesus Christ
enemy, Satan as the enemy of God
envy
children.comment: A desire for another's gifts, possessions, position or achievements, closely associated with jealousy.

children.title: Envy is the result of human sin
Envy arises from the good fortune of others
Envy arises from the spiritual abilities of others
In some cases, envy can be used by God

primaryrefs.comment: Paul hopes that the Gentiles' response to the gospel might make Israel want its blessings as well.

children.title: evil
children.comment: The presence of corruption, malevolence and depravity in the world, opposed to God's nature and will. Scripture stresses that evil is a force in its own right, rather than the mere absence of good, and describes its origins and the manner in which God deals with its continuing presence and power in his world.

children.title: evil, origins of
children.comment: Although Scripture does not reveal the ultimate origin of evil, it identifies a number of intermediate sources.

children.title: Satan as a source of evil

primaryrefs.comment: Identified later (Rev 12:9) with Satan

seealsos.comment: Satan incites David to take a census of Israel
Satan is responsible for a woman's crippling disease
The devil prompts Judas to betray Jesus Christ
Ananias lies to the Holy Spirit at Satan's instigation
Paul's thorn in the flesh from Satan

children.title: Fallen human nature as a source of evil

seealsos.comment: the love of money a root of evil
The tongue is a source of evil

children.title: Physical evil is a consequence of moral evil
evil, warnings against
children.comment: Scripture repeatedly warns against evil. It exposes it and reveals its consequences.

children.title: God's law given to counter evil
By leading believers away from evil
The state is ordained to restrain evil
evil, believers' responses to
children.comment: Scripture outlines several ways in which believers should respond to evil.

children.title: Evil is to be repaid with good
Believers should pray in response to evil
Believers should trust God in the face of evil
evil, victory over
children.comment: Although evil continues to be present and active in the world, Scripture gives an assurance that God will finally triumph over evil in all its forms.

children.title: Satan's power is already limited by God
Evil spirits are subject to God's control
Jesus Christ's triumph over evil powers
God's transforming power reverses the effects of evil in human lives
God brings good out of evil
The removal of the curse on creation
Jesus Christ's victory over evil is expressed in his thousand-year reign with believers, during which Satan is bound

seealsos.comment: Interpreters differ over whether the ``thousand years'' refers to a future period or to Jesus Christ's present rule in the world.

children.title: The final defeat of all evil powers
Evil will be excluded from the new heaven and earth
evil, examples of
children.comment: Biblical examples of evil are many and varied.

children.title: Evil disasters sent by God in judgment
Threats to Israel from other nations
evil, origins of
children.comment: Although Scripture does not reveal the ultimate origin of evil, it identifies a number of intermediate sources.

children.title: Satan as a source of evil

primaryrefs.comment: Identified later (Rev 12:9) with Satan

Evil will be excluded from the new heaven and earth

children.comment: Biblical examples of evil are many and varied.

children.title: Evil disasters sent by God in judgment
Threats to Israel from other nations
failure
children.comment: Scripture indicates various ways in which believers may fail God, while emphasising that God will never fail his people.

cschildren.title: God will never fail his people

children.title: faithlessness
children.comment: The lack or absence of faith, or the turning away from a professed commitment to God.

children.title: faithlessness, nature and causes of
children.comment: The abandoning of a commitment to the Lord, seen in disowning him, wandering from the truth and becoming entangled with the world, and resulting in judgment.

children.title: Ways in which faithlessness is seen

secondaryrefs.comment: These men had been excluded from the church, a sanctuary from Satan's power.

children.title: The faithlessness of those who fall away
True faith is proved by perseverance
Israel's unfaithfulness led to God's rejection
Warnings not to repeat Israel's unfaithfulness
faithlessness, as disobedience
children.comment: A lack of faith and obedience to God, which is seen especially in the lives of unbelievers. However, Scripture makes clear that believers can occasionally lapse into faithlessness towards God.

children.title: Their failure to trust God for deliverance

secondaryrefs.comment: Many Jews reject Paul's ministry in Rome
Paul's own persecution of the church arose from unbelief in Jesus Christ.
The Jews' rejection of the gospel opens the way for Gentiles to be incorporated into the people of God, represented here as branches grafted onto a cultivated olive tree.

children.title: Israel's faithlessness is partial and temporary

secondaryrefs.comment: Though the people as a whole have rejected Jesus Christ, a faithful remnant remains
God's purpose for the faithful of Israel is their ultimate salvation.

seealsos.comment: Fear during a storm at sea
inability to cast out a demon

secondaryrefs.comment: failure to learn from the lessons of the past
failure to accept teaching that has been given

children.title: faithlessness, nature and causes of
children.comment: The abandoning of a commitment to the Lord, seen in disowning him, wandering from the truth and becoming entangled with the world, and resulting in judgment.

children.title: Ways in which faithlessness is seen

secondaryrefs.comment: These men had been excluded from the church, a sanctuary from Satan's power.

children.title: The faithlessness of those who fall away
True faith is proved by perseverance
Israel's unfaithfulness led to God's rejection
Warnings not to repeat Israel's unfaithfulness
faithlessness, as disobedience
children.comment: A lack of faith and obedience to God, which is seen especially in the lives of unbelievers. However, Scripture makes clear that believers can occasionally lapse into faithlessness towards God.

children.title: Their failure to trust God for deliverance

secondaryrefs.comment: Many Jews reject Paul's ministry in Rome
Paul's own persecution of the church arose from unbelief in Jesus Christ.
The Jews' rejection of the gospel opens the way for Gentiles to be incorporated into the people of God, represented here as branches grafted onto a cultivated olive tree.

children.title: Israel's faithlessness is partial and temporary

secondaryrefs.comment: Though the people as a whole have rejected Jesus Christ, a faithful remnant remains
God's purpose for the faithful of Israel is their ultimate salvation.

seealsos.comment: Fear during a storm at sea
inability to cast out a demon

secondaryrefs.comment: failure to learn from the lessons of the past
failure to accept teaching that has been given

children.title: false Christs
children.comment: Mistaken and deceptive people claiming to be Jesus Christ. Jesus Christ warns his followers to be on their guard against the appearance of such people.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ warns that false Christs will appear
False Christs will perform signs and miracles in order to deceive
False Christs can be recognised because the return of Jesus Christ will be obvious to everyone

primaryrefs.comment: The personal return of the Lord Jesus Christ is not described in terms of an appearance to a select group, but to the whole world. The attempt of anyone to convince others that he is Christ therefore is a sure sign of deception.

children.title: false gods
children.comment: Any gods other than the LORD himself. Some of these divinities took the form of images, others were mythical. Some Israelites became involved in idolatrous worship of such gods. The book of Acts records attempts to deify human beings.

cschildren.title: False gods associated with foreign nations in the OT

children.title: Amon, the chief god of Egypt

primaryrefs.comment: Asherah was the consort of El, the chief Canaanite god. Wooden poles, perhaps carved in her image, were often set up in her honour and placed near other pagan objects of worship.

seealsos.comment: Elijah summons 400 prophets of Asherah to Mount Carmel.

children.title: Ashtoreth, a goddess of war and fertility

primaryrefs.comment: Ashtoreth, the consort of Baal, was associated with the evening star and was worshipped as Ishtar in Babylon and as Athtart in Aram. To the Greeks she was Astarte or Aphrodite and to the Romans, Venus.

children.title: Baal, a Canaanite and Phoenician god of fertility and rain

primaryrefs.comment: Baal, meaning ``lord'', was pictured standing on a bull, a popular symbol of fertility and strength. Baal was associated with Asherah and Ashtoreth, goddesses of fertility.

children.title: Baal-Zebub, a popular deity of the Philistines

primaryrefs.comment: Beelzebub is the Greek form of the Hebrew name ``Baal-Zebub'', meaning ``lord of the flies''.

children.title: Bel, the chief deity of Babylon

primaryrefs.comment: Bel was another name for the sun god, Marduk. Nebo, the god of learning and writing was the son of Marduk.

children.title: Chemosh, the chief god of Moab
Dagon, worshipped in Babylonia and Philistia
Molech, the chief deity of Ammon

seealsos.comment: The practice of sacrificing children to Molech was common in Phoenicia and the region
Josiah destroyed the area where the altars for child sacrifice were located

cschildren.title: The worship of false gods was a snare to God's people

children.title: Numerous attempts were made to stop the worship of Baal and other false gods
Attempts to stop false worship proved unsuccessful

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``Baal'' was not orginally a proper name but came to be used as such.

cschildren.title: Warnings against and condemnation of, the worship of false gods

primaryrefs.comment: Nebuchadnezzar came to realise the foolishness of worshipping false gods

cschildren.title: The first Christians were confronted with the worship of Greek and Roman deities

primaryrefs.comment: Zeus was the patron god of the city of Lystra and his temple was there. Paul was identified as the god Hermes (the Roman Mercury), Zeus' attendant and spokesman.
Artemis was the Greek name for the Roman goddess, Diana.

seealsos.comment: the two ``sons of Zeus'', regarded as the guardian deities of sailors

children.title: false religion
children.comment: The worship of anything that is not God, including any form of religion that fails to do justice to the glory and majesty of God. Scripture criticises both the practices and the beliefs of false religions.

primaryrefs.comment: The dragon in Revelation may be understood as the devil and the beast as the antichrist: the forces at work behind the human authorities that defy the rule of God.

cschildren.title: False religion is based on man-made traditions, myths and philosophies

children.title: It offers no help in time of need
It prevents people from finding the truth

cschildren.title: False religion receives the full force of God's anger

children.title: false teachers
children.comment: Those who teach error and in so doing lead others astray. They are to be distinguished from false prophets who are equally condemned in Scripture.

cschildren.title: The OT prophets warned God's people against being led astray by false teachers

children.title: He identified the teachers of the law and Pharisees as false teachers
He warned his followers against them

cschildren.title: The condemnation of false teachers in the early church

children.title: Paul urges his readers to avoid false teachers

seealsos.comment: The Corinthian church had been undiscerningly tolerant of Jewish deceivers in their midst

children.title: Hymenaeus and Philetus are cited as examples of false teachers
Those who teach will be judged particularly strictly
false teachings
children.comment: Scripture repeatedly warns against false teachings, which deny or distort some aspect of the gospel. The origin of such teachings is attributed either to human error or to demonic inspiration.

children.title: They are destructive in their nature
They have the capacity to lead people astray
They may be accompanied by miraculous signs
Holding fast to the true gospel
false witness
children.comment: The telling of lies about another so as to make them appear guilty when they are innocent. Condemned in Scripture, false witness was experienced by Jesus Christ and is to be expected by those who follow him.

cschildren.title: False witness is condemned in Scripture
False witness arises from an evil heart
False witness will be subject to judgment
Examples of those who were the victims of false witness
False witness against believers is to be expected by them

children.title: false worship
children.comment: Forms of worship that are not worthy of God, especially worship offered without sincerity and obedience or that is contrary to the commands of God.

children.title: Worship conducted in disobedience to God
Worship and sacrifices offered by those who were not priests
Worship lacking in due humility and reverence
Worship conducted in ignorance of God

cschildren.title: Scripture vividly contrasts false worship with true worship

children.title: True worship involves the worshipper's heart, soul and mind

secondaryrefs.comment: True worship involves the whole of a person's life and not just formal acts of worship.

children.title: True worship is in the spirit
favouritism
children.comment: The unfair treatment of a person or group in preference to another. Favouritism is shown in Scripture as causing division both in the family and in the church. It is warned against in the administration of justice. The human tendency to partiality is contrasted with God's impartial dealings.

children.title: The child of a favourite wife must not receive preferential treatment
James warned against favouring rich Christians
Paul warned Timothy against showing favouritism
God does not differentiate between Jewish and Gentile Christians
fear
children.comment: An attitude of anxiety or distress, caused by concern over a threat to one's future. Scripture provides numerous examples of situations in which fear is experienced. It declares, however, that God alone is to be feared, and moments of human fear can be opportunities for deepening faith in him.

children.title: Fear of the unknown or the abnormal

seealsos.comment: The radiance of Moses' face reflected God's glory and made the Israelites afraid
Belshazzar's fear at the writing on the wall
the fear of the disciples at the transfiguration
Fear seized the people when the Gerasene demoniac was healed
the disciples fear of Paul, not believing his conversion
Christians, assured of God's love, no longer fear judgment

cschildren.title: Fear as an opportunity for faith

children.title: folly
children.comment: A human attitude of lack of wisdom or contempt for wisdom, which shows itself in a lack of understanding and obedience. Scripture contrasts human foolishness with divine wisdom, and indicates the serious consequences of a rejection of the wisdom of God.

children.title: folly, examples of
children.comment: Human folly is seen in rebellion against God, ignoring his way and will, a failure to understand him: and moral or spiritual irresponsibility.

seealsos.comment: seeking foreign help rather than trusting God

primaryrefs.comment: The shepherds are those entrusted with the task of guiding and caring for God's people

secondaryrefs.comment: Nabal. In Hebrew this name means ``fool''.

primaryrefs.comment: Paul engages in what he admits is the foolish boasting of his accomplishments in order to challenge the claims of false ``apostles''.

children.title: Human wisdom is foolishness to God
folly, effects of
children.comment: The attitude that leads to a closing of the mind towards God and his truth, and a false self-confidence, which results in being easily led astray, failure to see danger, unpreparedness and ultimate ruin.

children.title: Folly gives a false basis for confidence

seealsos.comment: failure to understand the nature of death and resurrection

children.title: Folly opens the way to deception
Exclusion from God's way of salvation
folly, examples of
children.comment: Human folly is seen in rebellion against God, ignoring his way and will, a failure to understand him: and moral or spiritual irresponsibility.

seealsos.comment: seeking foreign help rather than trusting God

primaryrefs.comment: The shepherds are those entrusted with the task of guiding and caring for God's people

secondaryrefs.comment: Nabal. In Hebrew this name means ``fool''.

primaryrefs.comment: Paul engages in what he admits is the foolish boasting of his accomplishments in order to challenge the claims of false ``apostles''.

children.title: Human wisdom is foolishness to God
folly, effects of
children.comment: The attitude that leads to a closing of the mind towards God and his truth, and a false self-confidence, which results in being easily led astray, failure to see danger, unpreparedness and ultimate ruin.

children.title: Folly gives a false basis for confidence

seealsos.comment: failure to understand the nature of death and resurrection

children.title: Folly opens the way to deception
Exclusion from God's way of salvation
fools
children.comment: Those who lack wisdom and understanding, especially in relation to God.

children.title: fools, characteristics of
children.comment: Scripture portrays fools as those who have rejected God and his ways and are unable or unwilling to appreciate the wisdom of knowing and obeying him.

children.title: The world regards Christians as fools
The world regards the gospel as foolish
Fools do not believe in God
Fools act in a godless manner
Fools give vent to their anger
The words of fools are empty
Fools rely on words, not deeds
fools, in teaching of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Jesus Christ speaks about those whose words and actions demonstrate opposition to, or disregard for, the wisdom of God revealed in his words and through the Scriptures, and in parables points to the serious consequences of folly.

primaryrefs.comment: The Pharisees demonstrate foolishness by attaching undue significance to what is less important whilst neglecting what really matters.
The Pharisees were concerned with the externals of religion. Jesus Christ is concerned, also, with the inner life.
The foolishness of trusting in wealth and not in God.
The foolishness of being unprepared for the coming of God's kingdom.

children.title: fools, characteristics of
children.comment: Scripture portrays fools as those who have rejected God and his ways and are unable or unwilling to appreciate the wisdom of knowing and obeying him.

children.title: The world regards Christians as fools
The world regards the gospel as foolish
Fools do not believe in God
Fools act in a godless manner
Fools give vent to their anger
The words of fools are empty
Fools rely on words, not deeds
fools, in teaching of Jesus Christ
children.comment: Jesus Christ speaks about those whose words and actions demonstrate opposition to, or disregard for, the wisdom of God revealed in his words and through the Scriptures, and in parables points to the serious consequences of folly.

primaryrefs.comment: The Pharisees demonstrate foolishness by attaching undue significance to what is less important whilst neglecting what really matters.
The Pharisees were concerned with the externals of religion. Jesus Christ is concerned, also, with the inner life.
The foolishness of trusting in wealth and not in God.
The foolishness of being unprepared for the coming of God's kingdom.

children.title: forgetting
children.comment: The process of accidentally or deliberately failing to remember people, events or ideas. Scripture rebukes those who forget the past work of God in history or in their lives or who neglect their present responsibilities towards God in order to please themselves.

children.title: Forgetting can be caused by idolatry
Forgetting can be caused by pride
Forgetting can be caused by drinking
Forgetting can be caused by affliction

cschildren.title: Forgetting God's acts in the past

children.title: Forgetting God brings suffering on the individual
Forgetting God brings suffering on others

primaryrefs.comment: David's forgetting of God in his adultery with Bathsheba led to her husband Uriah suffering death through David's manipulation of events.

children.title: Forgetting God brings destruction on the nation

cschildren.title: People may sometimes feel that God has forgotten them
God promises never to forget his people
Things God urges believers to forget

children.title: forgetting God
children.comment: Scripture warns people how easy it is to forget God in the varying circumstances of life and to fail to give him his due place, and points out the consequences of so doing.

cschildren.title: Exhortations and resolve not to forget God
God's provision to help people not to forget him
God's challenge to those who forget him
God's call to those who forget him
God's grace even when his people do forget him

children.title: grudge
children.comment: A persistent feeling of ill will or resentment held by one person against another, often as the result of an injury or insult. Christians are not to bear grudges against others; instead they are to forgive those who have wronged them.

cschildren.title: Examples of those who held grudges

children.title: The Israelites against Moses and Aaron

cschildren.title: Severe grudges that led to hatred and murder

children.title: That of Joseph by his brothers, averted by Reuben
That of Amnon, on the orders of Absalom
That of John the Baptist by Herodias

cschildren.title: Warnings against the holding of grudges

children.title: heresies
children.comment: Teachings held by a factional religious party which deny some aspect of established doctrine. NT writers give no toleration to heresies in the church.

cschildren.title: Heresies and the factional nature of Judaism

children.title: Christianity was perceived as a heresy within Judaism
The imposition of Jewish regulations on Gentile converts
Heresies concerning the person of Jesus Christ
Heresies concerning the return of Jesus Christ
hypocrisy
children.comment: An outward pretence masking an inner reality. Scripture condemns hypocrisy, especially in matters of faith. Believers should express their commitment to God in their words and their deeds, as well as in their inner motivation.

children.title: When deeds do not match words

cschildren.title: Hypocrisy is not to be found in leaders

primaryrefs.comment: By acting in this way, Peter was denying his own conviction that Gentiles could be saved by faith without having to submit to the law.

cschildren.title: Examples of those who did not practise hypocrisy
